{{Infobox museum |name = National Softball Hall of Fame and Museum |image = |imagesize = |caption = |map_type = Oklahoma |map_caption = Location of the Hall of Fame and Museum in Oklahoma |coordinates = {{coord|35.5233376|-97.4631822|display=inline}} |established = 1957, expanded in 1976{{cite web|url=http://www.okcadventure.com/attractions/softball-hall-of-fame/ |title=Softball Hall of Fame - Oklahoma City's Adventure District |accessdate=August 30, 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090212124617/http://okcadventure.com/attractions/softball-hall-of-fame/ |archivedate=February 12, 2009|df= }} |dissolved = |location = 2801 NE 50th Street
in the Adventure District of [[Oklahoma City]], [[Oklahoma]], United States |type = [[Hall of fame]] |visitors = |director = |curator = |publictransit = |website = [http://www.asasoftball.com/hall_of_fame/index.asp Official Website] }} '''National Softball Hall of Fame and Museum''' is a [[softball]] museum located in [[Oklahoma City]]'s Adventure District. It includes the [[ASA Hall of Fame Stadium|Don E. Porter Hall of Fame Stadium]], home to the [[World Cup of Softball]] and the annual [[Women's College World Series]]. ==Amateur Softball Association== {{See also|USA Softball#National Softball Hall of Fame and museum}} [[USA Softball]] (formerly the [[Amateur Softball Association]]) operates the National Softball Hall of Fame and Museum. ==British Hall== On 17 February 2007, the [[British Softball Federation]] enshrined 12 members into its inaugural Hall of Fame. Members included players Kate Allen, GB manager/player Mark Berman, the late umpire Dave Allen, and Natalie Fox.{{cite web|url=http://www.baseballsoftballuk.com/gen_insert.php?from_level3=Articles&db_story=1258&this_page=softballnews&back=Current++News|title=First Members Chosen for BSF Hall of Fame|accessdate=August 30, 2009|deadurl=yes|archiveurl=https://archive.is/20070928090533/http://www.baseballsoftballuk.com/gen_insert.php?from_level3=Articles&db_story=1258&this_page=softballnews&back=Current++News|archivedate=September 28, 2007|df=}} ==See also== *[[National Fastpitch Coaches Association Hall of Fame]] ==References== {{reflist}} ==External links== *[http://www.asasoftball.com/hall_of_fame/index.asp National Softball Hall of Fame and Museum] * [http://www.travelok.com/listings/view.profile/id.299 National Softball Hall of Fame and Museum information on TravelOK.com] Official travel and tourism website for the State of Oklahoma * [http://www.softballtracker.com/team/index.php?team=1437 Team Rich Softball] {{DEFAULTSORT:National Softball Hall Of Fame And Museum}} [[Category:Amateur Softball Association|Hall of Fame and Museum]] [[Category:Softball museums and halls of fame]] [[Category:Halls of fame in Oklahoma|Softball]] [[Category:Sports museums in Oklahoma]] [[Category:American national museums in Oklahoma]] [[Category:Museums in Oklahoma City]] [[Category:Sports in Oklahoma City]] [[Category:Awards established in 1957]] [[Category:Museums established in 1957]] [[Category:1957 establishments in Oklahoma]] {{Oklahoma-museum-stub}} {{OklahomaCity-stub}}

{{Infobox stadium | stadium_name = Newark Schools Stadium | nickname = | image = | location = 450 Bloomfield Avenue, [[Roseville, Newark, New Jersey]] 07102 | coordinates = {{coord|40.769866|-74.184612|display=it|type:landmark}} | broke_ground = | opened = 1925 (original stadium)
2011 (current stadium) | demolished = 2009 | owner = | operator = | surface = Grass (original stadium)
Artificial (current) | construction_cost = | architect = | former_names = | tenants = [[Newark Stars]] ([[Eastern Colored League|ECL]]) (1926)
[[Newark Tornadoes]] ([[NFL]]) (1930)
Newark Tornadoes ([[American Association (football)|AA]]) (1930, 1937-1938)
Newark Bears (AA) (1939-1941, 1963-1964))
[[Newark Ukrainian Sitch]] ([[American Soccer League (1933-1983)|ASL]]) (1967-1968)
Newark City Schools (1925-2006) | seating_capacity = 15,000 |}} '''Newark Schools Stadium''' (nicknamed "'''The Old Lady of Bloomfield Avenue'''") is the name of two stadiums that were both located on Bloomfield Avenue between Abingdon and Roseville Avenues in the [[Roseville, Newark, New Jersey|Roseville]] section of [[Newark, New Jersey]]. The first stadium was used primarily for [[American football|football]] and was built in 1925. It was the home of the [[Newark Tornadoes]] of the [[National Football League]] during the [[1930 NFL season|1930 season]]. The stadium was used for high school football until 2006. [[baseball|Baseball's]] [[Newark Stars]] of the [[Eastern Colored League]], which was a part of the [[Negro Leagues]], also used the stadium in 1926. Its primary use, however, was for Newark's high schools. The original stadium was a reinforced concrete horseshoe shaped venue that had a maximum seating capacity of 25,000. The original stadium was condemned in 2006 and demolished in 2009. In its place, a brand new Schools Stadium was constructed on the site and the new stadium opened in 2011. The current Schools Stadium shares some design elements with its predecessor but seats far fewer people (5,600) in two metal bleacher sections. It currently plays host to football games played by [[Barringer High School]], [[East Side High School (Newark, New Jersey)|East Side High School]], and [[Newark Collegiate Academy]]. The new Schools Stadium is one of three venues used by Newark's high schools; [[Malcolm X Shabazz High School|Shabazz High School]] and [[Weequahic High School]] both have football stadiums. Shabazz's field, Shabazz Stadium, is also used by [[Central High School (Newark, New Jersey)|Newark Central High School]]. Weequahic's Untermann Field is also home to [[West Side High School (Newark, New Jersey)|West Side High School]]'s football team. ==Soccer== For the 1967-68 ASL (American Soccer League) season, the Newark Ukrainian Sitch club moved its home games to this field. Prior to that season, 'Sitch' played at Ironbound field. The move to an approx. 25,000 capacity ground was welcomed as an improvement. The crowds never filled the stadium however and the Ukrainian Weekly refers to crowds only in the hundreds rather than thousands.''The Ukrainian Weekly'', September 30, 1967 (online archive at http://www.ukrweekly.com) ==Football== After the Tornadoes folded, Newark's [[American Association (football)|American Association]] team became the primary tenants for the stadium. The American Association was the first attempt at establishing a farm system for the NFL. In 1937, the Tornadoes left [[Orange, New Jersey]] again for Newark. The team was once again called the Newark Tornadoes. In 1939, the team was purchased by [[George Halas]], the owner of the [[Chicago Bears]], and called the Newark Bears. The Bears played in the stadium until [[World War II]]; the Newark Bombers would play in the same league and stadium in 1946 after the war ended. In 1963, [[Orlando Panthers|another Bears franchise]] would arrive when the Paterson Miners of the [[Atlantic Coast Football League]] moved to Newark, took on the Bears name, and played through 1965; its last year in Newark was in the [[Continental Football League]]. Another Continental league team, the [[Jersey Jays]], played its 1969 season in Newark before moving to nearby Jersey City in 1970. Most of Newark's public school football teams played at the stadium as well until 2006. The Stadium also served, since 1955 until its closing for reconstruction, as the home of the North Newark Little League (formerly the Saint Francis Xavier Little League). ==Baseball== Schools Stadium was also used for baseball. In 1926, the [[Newark Stars]] of the Negro Leagues' [[Eastern Colored League]] played at stadium. When the stadium was configured for baseball, the distance down the foul lines was so short, that balls hit over the fence were ground rule [[Double (baseball)|doubles]]. High school teams also used the field for baseball until 2006. The Stadium was also the original home of what has become one of the largest youth baseball programs in the City of Newark - the North Newark Little League. Formerly the St. Francis Xavier Little League, the youth of the program utilized the baseball fields from 1955. It was the last organization to have continued use of the facility (even after it was condemned in 2006) right up to the point of its closing for reconstruction. ==Track and field== Olympian [[Jesse Owens]], once ran [[track and field|track]] there and lost to a Newark local named [[Eulace Peacock]]. Meanwhile, another Olympian, [[Milt Campbell]] began his track career at Newark Schools Stadium. The National Women's Olympic Trials also were held in the stadium in 1928. ==Riots== During the [[1967 Newark riots]], Schools Stadium served as the staging area for the [[New Jersey National Guard]], who were summoned to Newark to reinforce the overwhelmed [[Newark Police Department]]. ==Decline and a new stadium== Years of neglect allowed the stadium to experience a large amount of deterioration and compromised structural integrity. At various points in its later years, parts of the stadium's wooden bleachers were blocked off with fencing to prevent spectators from sitting in these seats. In 2006, a capital bond request was approved by the Newark City Council that included $63.7 million in funding for 14 projects that ranged from a new robotics center to the rebuilding of Schools Stadium. In Fall 2006, Schools Stadium was condemned and three years later the stadium was demolished. Barringer and East Side moved their games to Untermann Field while the new stadium was being constructed. {{s-start}} {{succession box | title = Home of the [[Orange Tornadoes|Orange A.C.- Orange/Newark Tornadoes]] | years = 1930 | before = [[Knights of Columbus Stadium]] | after = [[Newark Velodrome]] }} {{succession box | title = Home of the [[Orange Tornadoes|Orange A.C.- Orange/Newark Tornadoes]] | years = 1937-1965 | before = [[Knights of Columbus Stadium]] | after = None }} {{end}} ==References== *[http://www.profootballresearchers.org/Linescores/1930.pdf 1930 NFL season summary] *[http://www.nj.com/sports/ledger/izenbergcol/index.ssf/2009/04/a_dream_turns_into_a_shame_new.html Izenberg: A dream turns into a shame: Newark Schools Stadium to be demolished] *[http://www.nj.com/sports/njsports/index.ssf/2009/07/construction_of_new_super_site.html Construction of new super site finally underway at iconic Newark Schools Stadium] *[http://baseball-fever.com/showthread.php?t=67365 Baseball Fever: List of Negro League stadiums] *[http://www.projectballpark.org/history/ecl/newark.html Project Ballpark: Newark Schools Stadium] {{Orange Tornadoes}} {{Defunct NFL stadiums}} [[Category:Orange/Newark Tornadoes]] [[Category:Sports venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Defunct National Football League venues]] [[Category:American football venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues in Newark, New Jersey]] [[Category:1925 establishments in New Jersey]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 1925]] [[Category:Sports venues demolished in 2009]] [[Category:Sports venues completed in 2011]] [[Category:High school football venues in the United States]] [[Category:Defunct baseball venues in the United States]] [[Category:Baseball venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Soccer venues in New Jersey]] [[Category:Athletics (track and field) venues in New Jersey]]

revision.text:
{{Distinguish|Rogaine (drug)}} {{Infobox sport | image = HFsummit2001.jpg | imagesize = 300px | caption = Competitors at a checkpoint | union = | nickname = | first = [[Australia]] | registered = | clubs = | contact = | team = 2–5 | mgender = Mixed | category = Outdoor | ball = | olympic = }} [[Image:Orienteering symbol.svg|thumb|right|150px|The standard international [[orienteering]] symbol is used to designate a '''''checkpoint''''' on rogaining courses.]]
'''Rogaining''' is an [[orienteering]] sport of long distance cross-country [[navigation]],<ref>{{Cite book |first1=N. |last1=Phillips |first2=R. |last2=Phillips |year=2000 |title=Rogaining Cross-Country Navigation |publisher=Outdoor Recreation in Australia |isbn=0-9593329-2-8}}</ref> involving both route planning and navigation between checkpoints using a variety of map types. In a rogaine, teams of 2–5 people choose which checkpoints to visit within a time limit with the intent of maximizing their score. Teamwork, endurance, competition and an appreciation for the natural environment are features of the sport. Championship rogaines are 24 hours long, but rogaines can be as short as two hours.
==History== Rogaining can trace its roots back to 1947 when the first of many events with some of the features of rogaines was organized by the [[Melbourne University]] Mountaineering Club. The events from the 1940s eventually led to the birth of the sport of rogaining in April 1976, in [[Melbourne]], [[Australia]]. The sport was named, rules were adopted and the world’s first rogaining association was formed (the Victorian Rogaining Association). Growth of the association and the sport occurred rapidly over the next decade.
The word rogaining is derived from the names of three of the founders, Rod Phillips, Gail Davis (née Phillips) and Neil Phillips (RoGaiNe, hence 'rogaining', 'rogainer' etc.) who were all members of the [[Surrey-Thomas Rover Crew]] which organized the world's first rogaine. The name was formally adopted by the Victorian Rogaining Association at its inaugural annual general meeting in August 1976 and accepted by [[Scouts Australia]] and University [[hiking|bushwalking]] groups to give the new sport an identity in its own right.<ref>{{cite book |title = Which Way's North? |publisher = Victorian Rogaining Association |year = 2010 |url = http://vra.rogaine.asn.au/getting-started/which-ways-north.html |format = PDF |accessdate = 2010-03-08 |page = 5 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110301175943/http://www.vra.rogaine.asn.au/getting-started/which-ways-north.html |archivedate = 2011-03-01 |df = }}</ref>
[[World Rogaining Championships]] were first held in 1992, and then every two years from 1996 to 2012. Since then they have been held annually, with the country chosen two years in advance by the [[International Rogaining Federation]]. As of 2017 this has changed back again to every two years.
* 1st World Rogaining Championship (1992): Beechworth, Australia, about 200 teams * [http://wa.rogaine.asn.au/index.php/results/220-everlasting-results 2nd World Rogaining Championship (1996)]: Mt Singleton, Western Australia, 640 participants in 271 teams * 3rd World Rogaining Championship (1998): Kamloops, British Columbia, Canada * 4th World Rogaining Championship (2000): Christchurch, New Zealand * 5th World Rogaining Championship (2002): Lesna, Czech Republic, 202 teams * 6th World Rogaining Championship (2004): Arizona, USA, 380 participants from 15 countries and 33 U.S. states. * [https://web.archive.org/web/20120213184843/http://www.nswrogaining.org/AboutEvents/Events/06WC/index.htm 7th World Rogaining Championships (2006)]: New South Wales, Australia; 691 participants (311 teams), 125 from overseas * [http://8wrc2008.rogain.ee/ 8th World Rogaining Championship (2008)]: Karula National Park, Estonia; 748 participants (339 teams) from 22 countries. * [http://wrc2010.org.nz/ 9th World Rogaining Championship (2010)]: Cheviot, New Zealand; 522 participants (251 teams) * [http://www.rogaining.cz/wrc2012/en/ 10th World Rogaining Championship (2012)]: Přebuz, Czech Republic * [https://web.archive.org/web/20121208013741/http://wrc2013.com/ 11th World Rogaining Championship (2013)]: Alol, Russian Federation * [http://peakassurance.net/ 12th World Rogaining Championship (2014)]: Black Hills, South Dakota, USA * [http://wrc2015.rogaining.fi 13th World Rogaining Championship (2015)]: Lapland, Finland * [https://web.archive.org/web/20150103205202/http://worldrogainingchamps.com.au/ 14th World Rogaining Championship (2016)]: Alice Springs, Australia * [http://wrc2017.rogaining.lv/en/index.php? 15th World Rogaining Championship (2017)]: [[Rāzna National Park]], Latvia * 16th World Rogaining Championship (2019): [[La Molina (ski resort)|La Molina]], [[Catalonia]], Spain
==Basic play== {{unreferenced section|date=February 2018}} Teams of two to five members visit as many checkpoints as possible in the time allowed. Shorter duration rogaines often allow solo competitors. Checkpoints are scored differently depending on level of difficulty in reaching them; therefore teams choose a strategy (for example, to visit many low score checkpoints). Teams travel entirely on foot, navigating by map and compass between checkpoints in terrain that varies from open farmland to hilly forest. A central base camp known as a "hash house" provides hot meals throughout the event and teams may return at any time to eat, rest or sleep. Teams travel at their own pace and anyone from children to grandparents can experience the personal satisfaction that comes from cross-country navigation at their own level of competition and comfort. Team members stay within earshot of each other.
The duration of a championship rogaine is 24 hours, but shorter variations such as 3-, 6-, 8-, 12- and 15-hour events are also held (sometimes concurrently with a 24-hour event). Depending on the terrain, experienced rogaining teams can cover more than one hundred kilometers over the 24-hour period. There have also been longer events (dubbed "Endurogaines") lasting 48 and 50 hours. In their native Australia, rogaines are usually held every month during weekends near full moons, with annual state championships and an annual national championship. They require dozens of volunteers to run, including course setters and caterers and are often attended by hundreds of participants. A competitive 24-hour rogaine requires a map area of around 250 km<sup>2</sup> (c. 100 mi<sup>2</sup>), for relatively flat terrain; terrain with significant climbs may require far less or far more area, depending on the placement of checkpoints.
==Variants== [[Image:Rogainecontrol.jpg|thumb|right|upright|Rogaine control placed on a small knoll. While some controls can be relatively easy to spot, many require careful navigation to locate.]]Other forms of rogaining are popular, particularly in [[Australia]] during the months when normal rogaines are not held because of the weather. Popular variations include:
* Metrogaine: An event of usually around 6 hours and held in predominantly urban areas. * Cyclogaine: Usually run for six hours in areas with trails suitable for [[mountainbiking]]. * Snogaine: Held in areas that are snowbound and participants may either [[snowshoe]] or [[skiing|ski]] to reach checkpoints. * Paddlogaine: A rogaine on a water covered area, such as a set of interconnected lakes. Participants can generally use any human-powered [[watercraft]].
==See also== *[[Adventure race]] *[[Fell running]] *[[Orienteering]]
==References== <references/>
==External links== * [http://www.rogaining.com/ International Rogaining Federation] * [http://rogaine.asn.au/ Australian Rogaining Association ] * [https://qldrogaine.asn.au/ Qld Rogaining Association (Australia)] * [http://nswrogaining.org/ NSW Rogaining Association (Australia)] * [http://vra.rogaine.asn.au/ Victorian Rogaining Association (Australia)] * [https://wa.rogaine.asn.au/ Western Australian Rogaining Association (Australia)] * [https://sarogaining.com.au/ South Australian Rogaining Association (Australia)] * [https://rt.asn.au/ Tasmanian Rogaining Association (Australia)] * [http://act.rogaine.asn.au/ ACT Rogaining Association (Australia)] * [http://nt.rogaine.asn.au/ Northern Territory Rogaining Association (Australia)] {{Orienteering|type=concepts}} {{Racing unassisted human}}

{{Infobox racecourse |name = Sunland Park Racetrack & Casino |image = [[File:Sunland Park Racetrack.jpeg|frameless]] |caption = |website = [http://www.sunland-park.com] |location = [[Sunland Park, New Mexico|Sunland Park]], [[New Mexico]] |coordinates = |owner = Stanley E. Fulton |opened = 1959 |closed = |channel = |racetype = Thoroughbred and quarter horse |coursetype = |notableraces = }}
'''Sunland Park Racetrack & Casino''' is a [[racino]] located in [[Sunland Park, New Mexico]], a [[suburb]] of [[El Paso, Texas]].
Opened in 1959 as a [[Thoroughbred racing]] track, Sunland Park was the only legalized gambling venue in the region for many years. In 1999, at a time when horse racing was experiencing a decline as [[casino]]s and [[New Mexico Lottery|lotteries]] became commonplace, New Mexico legislators allowed [[slot machine]]s at the track. Now with over 700 machines in play, racing at Sunland has benefited greatly, with purses increasing from a $35,000 daily average in the early 1990s to nearly a quarter million per day today.<ref name="racing">[http://www.sunland-park.com/racing.htm Sunland-Park.com: Racing history]</ref>
Sunland Park was the track where [[jockey]]s [[Jerry Bailey]], [[Pat Valenzuela]], and [[Cash Asmussen]] got their starts. [[Bill Shoemaker]], who hails from the area, also rode at Sunland.<ref name="racing"/>
The casino, open 112 hours a week, also offers many electronic table games including roulette, blackjack and Texas Hold 'Em.<ref>[http://sunland-park.com/about/ Sunland-Park.com: About Sunland Park Racetrack & Casino]</ref>
The 2018 racing season, which features both Thoroughbreds and [[Quarter Horse]]s, runs from December 28 through May 5. Live racing is traditionally offered four days each week on Tuesdays, Fridays, Saturdays, and Sundays. Year-round [[Simulcast]] wagering is also available on racetracks across the country.
The live racing season is highlighted by the [[Sunland Derby]], run at 1⅛ miles for three-year-olds in late March of each year. The race was granted a Grade 3 status for the 2010 running and now is an important preparatory race for the [[Kentucky Derby]]. The graded ranking is important because the Kentucky Derby uses graded stakes earnings to determine which horse(s) will be permitted to enter if its limit of 20 entries is exceeded.
Other notable races include the $200,000 [[Sunland Park Oaks]], 1-1/16 miles Kentucky Oaks prep for fillies; the $100,000 Harry W. Henson Handicap for fillies and mares at one mile; the $100,000 Riley Allison Derby, 6½ [[furlong]]s for three-year-olds; the $100,000 Mine That Bird Derby, 1 1/16-mile prep for the Sunland Derby; and the $150,000 Sunland Park Handicap for three-year-olds and up at 1⅛ miles.
Sunland's top quarter horse race is the $350,000 Grade 1 Championship at Sunland Park, run late each December at 440 yards.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.ntra.com/content.aspx?type=news&id=26656 |title=WinStar Derby once again meet highlight|publisher=NTRA.com/''[[Daily Racing Form]]''|first=Mary|last=Rampellini|date=July 19, 2007 |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20070929083924/http://www.ntra.com/content.aspx?type=news&id=26656 |archivedate = September 29, 2007}}</ref> The $140,000 added New Mexican Spring Futurity at 300 yards is run in April.<ref>{{cite news|url=http://www.elpasotimes.com/sports/ci_6490957|publisher=''[[El Paso Times]]''|date=July 29, 2007|title=Sunland Park meet starts Dec. 12}}</ref> ==Gallery== <gallery> Image:SP Racetrack.jpg Image:SP Racetrack 1.jpg Image:SP Racetrack 2.jpg </gallery>
==References== {{reflist}}
==External links== * [http://www.sunland-park.com Official web site]

revision.text:
{{Infobox basketball biography | name = Tracy Gahan | image = | league = | team = | number = | position = [[Forward (basketball)|Forward]] | height_ft = 6 | height_in = 2 | weight_lbs = | birth_date = {{Birth date and age|1980|07|18|mf=y}} | birth_place = [[McKinney, Texas]] | nationality = American | high_school = [[McKinney High School|McKinney]] (McKinney, Texas) | college = [[Iowa State Cyclones women's basketball|Iowa State]] (1998–2002) | draft_league = WNBA | draft_year = 2002 | draft_round = 3 | draft_pick = 46 | draft_team = New York Liberty | career_start = 2003 | career_end = 2011 | years1 = 2003–2004 | team1 = [[Peiraikos Syndesmos|Peiraikos]] | years2 = 2004–2005 | team2 = [[Panathinaikos women's basketball|Panathinaikos]] | years3 = 2005–2006 | team3 = DCU Mercy | years4 = 2006–2009 | team4 = [[Adelaide Lightning]] | years5 = 2007 | team5 = [[Botaş SK]] | years6 = 2009–2010 | team6 = Pruszków | years7 = 2010 | team7 = Leszno | years8 = 2010–2011 | team8 = [[Dandenong Rangers]] | highlights = * [[WNBL Grand Final|WNBL champion]] ([[2007–08 WNBL season|2008]]) * [[Greek Women's Basketball League|A1 Ethniki champion]] (2005) * [[WNBL All-Star Five]] ([[2007–08 WNBL season|2008]]) }} '''Tracy Gahan''' (born July 18, 1980) is an American retired professional [[basketball]] player.
==Career== ===College=== In college, Gahan attended [[Iowa State University]] in [[Ames, Iowa]], playing for the [[Iowa State Cyclones|Cyclones]] in [[NCAA Division I]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyclones.com/roster.aspx?rp_id=882|title=Tracy Gahan - 1998-99 Basketball (W) Roster - Iowa State Athletics|publisher=cyclones.com}}</ref>
===WNBA=== After her college career, Gahan was picked 46th overall by the [[New York Liberty]] in the [[2002 WNBA draft]]. However, she was soon released. After strong showings during her championship season in Australia, Gahan was invited to the [[Connecticut Sun]]'s training camp before the [[2008 WNBA season]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.wnba.com/archive/wnba/sun/news/sunsigngahan.html|title=SUN: Sun Sign Gahan to Training Camp|publisher=wnba.com}}</ref> Gahan was released before the season began.
===Europe=== After spending an additional year at college to complete her degree, Gahan began her career in Greece. In 2003, she spent her first season with Peiraikos, before moving to Panathinaikos for her second season in [[Greek Women's Basketball League|A1 Ethniki Women's Basketball]].<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.cyclones.com/news/2006/6/23/323626.aspx|title=Q&A with Former Cyclone Women's Basketball Standout Tracy Gahan - Iowa State Athletics|publisher=cyclones.com}}</ref> In 2005, Gahan travelled west to Ireland, playing for [[DCU Mercy]] in the Irish Women's Super League. After a season away, she returned in 2007 after her Australian season concluded, signing with [[Botaş SK]] for the conclusion of the Turkish season.
After three years in Australia, Gahan played for PTS Lider Pruszków in Poland's [[Basket Liga Kobiet]]. Towards the end of the 2009–10 season, she switched to Tęcza Leszno for the remainder of her time in Poland.
===Australia=== In 2006, Gahan signed with the [[Adelaide Lightning]] to play in the [[Women's National Basketball League]], Australia's premier women's league and the strongest league in the southern hemisphere.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://websites.sportstg.com/team_info.cgi?action=PSTATS&pID=191728650&client=1-4478-56413-116972-5935177|title=Player statistics for TRACY GAHAN|publisher=sportstg.com}}</ref> In her second season with the Lightning, Gahan was awarded a place in the [[WNBL All-Star Five]] for [[2007–08 WNBL season|2007–08]]. The Lightning would also go on to take home the 2007–08 WNBL Championship. She returned to the league in 2010, signing with the [[Dandenong Rangers]].
==Personal life== Gahan is married to former [[Adelaide Lightning]] teammate, WNBA player and Australian Olympian, [[Erin Phillips]]. As of November 2016, she and Phillips have two children.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.adelaidenow.com.au/news/south-australia/crows-aflw-player-erin-phillips-opens-up-about-her-wife-tracy-gahan-and-new-twins/news-story/3ac858b5be50cd5c78fc1ca771c4b679|title=Crows AFLW player Erin Phillips opens up about her wife Tracy Gahan and new twins|publisher=adelaidenow.com.au}}</ref>
==References== {{reflist}}

revision.text:
{{Infobox museum | name = Vermont Ski and Snowboard Museum | image = | caption = | map_type = USA Vermont | map_caption = Location within Vermont | coordinates = {{coord|44|28|31|N|72|42|08|W|type:building_region:US-VT|format=dms|display=inline,title}} | established = {{Start date|1988}} | dissolved = | location = The Perkins Building
1 South Main Street
[[Stowe, Vermont]] | type = Sports museum | website = {{URL|http://www.vtssm.com/|VSSM}} }} The '''Vermont Ski and Snowboard Museum''' was established in [[Brandon, Vermont|Brandon]] in 1988 as ''The Vermont Ski Museum'', but was moved to [[Stowe, Vermont|Stowe]] in 2000 and opened to the public in its current location in 2002.{{cite web|title=Pacific Rim Alliance Ski History|url=http://www.pacificrimalliance.org/F.PublicAffairs/SkiHistory/museums.html#NewEngland|accessdate=11 October 2012}} In 2011 the word [[snowboarding]] was added to the museum's name.{{cite web|title=Vermont Ski Museum Adds Snowboarding|url=http://www.firsttracksonline.com/2011/06/01/vermont-ski-museum-adds-snowboarding/|publisher=First Tracks!! Online Media|accessdate=21 July 2012|date=June 1, 2011}} Currently the museum changes exhibits annually, with the exception of the [[Hall of Fame]]. The museum's main objective is to "collect, preserve, and celebrate Vermont's skiing and snowboarding history",{{cite web|title=VTSSM Home|url=http://www.vtssm.com/home|accessdate=17 July 2012}} and its mission is
"to utilize the resources belonging and accessible to the Vermont Ski and Snowboard Museum to create visually stimulating, historically in-depth exhibits that fulfill this mission that fulfill the mission to Collect, Preserve and Celebrate Vermont's Skiing and Snowboarding History".{{cite web|title=VTSSM Collections|url=http://www.vtssm.com/collections|accessdate=17 July 2012}}
== Location == The museum building was originally located in the 1818 Old Town Hall,{{cite web|last=Lonely Planet|title=Lonely Planet review for Vermont Ski Museum|url=http://www.lonelyplanet.com/usa/new-england/stowe/sights/museum/vermont-ski-museum|publisher=Lonely Planet.com|accessdate=27 July 2012}} but was moved during the 1860s.{{cite web|title=VTSSM Building|url=http://www.vtssm.com/collections/building|accessdate=17 July 2012}} The museum is now located in the Perkins Building at 1 South Main Street, [[Stowe, Vermont]].{{cite book|last=Allen|first=E. John B.|title=Historical Dictionary of Skiing|year=2011|publisher=Scarecrow Press|isbn=081-087-977-8|pages=nn|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=XayJ60PDwaoC&pg=PT248&lpg=PT248&dq=Vermont+Ski+and+Snowboard+Museum#v=onepage&q=Vermont%20Ski%20and%20Snowboard%20Museum&f=false}} A complete renovation took place in 2002. == Collection == {{As of|2012}} the museum offers a broad programming schedule, which comes in support of its collection containing 7,500 items, divided into seven different areas, together with comprehensive historical descriptions. * Ski and snowboard equipment. * Ski and snowboard clothing. * Mechanical equipment.{{cite web|title=VTSSM Objects|url=http://www.vtssm.com/collections/objects|accessdate=17 July 2012}} * Vermont Ski Area – specific location items. * The [[10th Mountain Division]] area. * The [[Fine art]] area. * The Related Library and Archival materials section includes over 800 items.{{cite web|title=VTSSM Library|url=http://www.vtssm.com/collections/library-a-archives|accessdate=17 July 2012}} The museum is participating in the digitization of historical films and collection of interviews.{{cite web|last=Stowe Reporter|title=Foundation, ski museum team up on video history|url=http://www.stowetoday.com/stowe_reporter/news/article_761fc4d8-3a2e-11e0-a1fb-001cc4c002e0.html|publisher=Stowe Today.com|accessdate=27 July 2012}} These resources might be made available to the general public.{{cite web|title=VTSSM Films|url=http://www.vtssm.com/collections/films-a-oral-histories|accessdate=17 July 2012}} To maintain the collections, the museum undertakes preservation activities, rotates exhibits, and makes them accessible to the general public. == Events == In addition to the exhibits, the museum hosts several annual events including the Stowe Mountain Film Festival,{{cite web|title=VTSSM Film Fest|url=http://www.vtssm.com/filmfestival|accessdate=19 July 2012}} the VT Antique Alpine Race,{{cite web|title=VTSSM Alpine|url=http://www.vtssm.com/aplinerace|accessdate=19 July 2012}} the VT Antique Nordic Race,{{cite web|title=VTSSM Nordic|url=http://www.vtssm.com/nordicrace|accessdate=19 July 2012}} the Epic Summer Event,{{cite web|title=VTSSM Epic|url=http://www.vtssm.com/epicsummer|accessdate=19 July 2012}} and the presentation of the Paul Robbins Ski Journalism Award.{{cite web|title=VTSSM Hall|url=http://www.vtssm.com/hall-of-fame|accessdate=17 July 2012}} == Hall of Fame == === Hall of Fame inductees === {| class="wikitable sortable" |- ! Inductee Name !! Year Inducted !! revision.text:
{{Infobox NRHP | name = Watertown Stadium | nrhp_type = | image = Watertown Stadium May 2017.jpg | caption = The stadium exterior, May 2017 | location= 1600 W Kemp Ave., [[Watertown, South Dakota]] | coordinates = {{coord|44.901958|-97.139558|display=inline,title}} | locmapin = South Dakota#USA | built = 1940 | architect = [[Perkins & McWayne]] |builder=[[Works Progress Administration]] | architecture = [[Art Deco architecture|Art Deco]] | added = July 5, 2000 | area = {{convert|3.7|acre|ha}} | governing_body = Local | mpsub = {{NRHP url|id=64500578|title=Federal Relief Construction in South Dakota MPS}} | refnum = 00000721{{NRISref|version=2009a}} }} '''Watertown Stadium''' is a [[stadium]] in [[Watertown, South Dakota]]. It was primarily used for [[baseball]] and [[American football]] and was the home of minor-league professional baseball including, most recently (c. 1970), the [[Watertown Expos]] of the [[Northern League (baseball, 1902–71)|Northern League]]. The ballpark has a capacity of 5,000 people and opened in 1940. It is currently used by [[Watertown High School (South Dakota)|Watertown High School]], to host baseball and football games. The stadium was built around the 1930s as [[Works Progress Administration]] Project 4265, and still holds the original plaque dedicating the structure. It is the home of the Watertown Arrows. In 2005, an additional building was built to the East of the field. This building houses restrooms, a concession stand, and both Varsity and Sophomore locker rooms. {{wide image|Watertown Stadium May 2017 pano.jpg|1000px|Panoramic view of the stadium interior configured for baseball, May 2017}} The stadium was listed on the [[National Register of Historic Places]] in 2000. It is built of reinforced concrete.{{cite web|url={{NRHP url|id=00000721}}|title=National Register of Historic Places Registration: Watertown Stadium |publisher=[[National Park Service]]|author=Megan D. Eades |date=January 2000 |accessdate=January 10, 2018}} With {{NRHP url|id=00000721|photos=y|title=two photos from 1999}}. Its NRHP nomination asserts:
The Watertown Stadium is a physical reminder of the unprecedented use of government aid to construct community improvements, particularly for recreation and leisure. Built in 1940, the stadium was reportedly planned as a band shelter, since the W.P.A. wanted to build them as part of their music project. According to a local story, the structure was built in phases, and it initially looked more like a bandshell. During the last phase of construction, it was then modified for use as an athletic stadium. Although the story is rumor, the existing structure is an excellent example of W.P.A. construction and one of the more outstanding federal relief projects in the northeastern part of the state.
